options.label: Compute & Application Runtime
options.description: Think: Where does my code live? App Services, Functions, Containers, AKS, VMs, Batch.
options.whenToUse: When defining where application code will execute - the foundation of any cloud architecture
options.whenNotToUse: This is almost always needed; skip only for pure data or networking scenarios

options.label: Data Stores & Persistence
options.description: Think: Where does my state live? SQL, NoSQL, Cache, Blob Storage, Data Lake, Synapse.
options.whenToUse: When you need data persistence, databases, or storage - the foundation for stateful applications
options.whenNotToUse: For purely stateless compute-only scenarios

options.label: Integration, Messaging & Workflow
options.description: Think: How do these things talk to each other? Service Bus, Event Grid, Event Hub, API Management, Logic Apps.
options.whenToUse: When building distributed systems requiring service communication, events, or workflow orchestration
options.whenNotToUse: For monolithic applications with direct function calls

options.label: Networking & Connectivity
options.description: Think: How does traffic flow? VNets, Private Endpoints, Application Gateway, Front Door, CDN, ExpressRoute.
options.whenToUse: When you need network infrastructure, connectivity, traffic routing, or security boundaries
options.whenNotToUse: For simple single-resource scenarios with default networking

options.label: Identity, Access, & Security Controls
options.description: Think: Who can touch what? Entra ID (Azure AD), Managed Identities, Key Vault, RBAC, Defender, Conditional Access.
options.whenToUse: When you need authentication, authorization, secrets management, or security compliance - critical for production
options.whenNotToUse: Only for development-only scenarios or public anonymous access

options.label: Observability & Operations
options.description: Think: How do I know it's alive? Application Insights, Log Analytics, Monitor, Alerts, Workbooks, Cost Management.
options.whenToUse: For any production system - observability should be built in from the start, not added after issues arise
options.whenNotToUse: Only for throwaway prototypes or single-use scripts

options.label: DevOps & Delivery
options.description: Think: How do I ship this? GitHub Actions, Azure DevOps Pipelines, Container Registry (ACR), IaC (Bicep/Terraform).
options.whenToUse: When you need repeatable deployments, CI/CD pipelines, or infrastructure automation - shapes the entire architecture lifecycle
options.whenNotToUse: For manual one-time deployments or pure exploration

options.label: AI, ML & Cognitive Services
options.description: Think: How do I add brains? OpenAI, Cognitive Search, ML Studio, Speech Services, Vision APIs, Document Intelligence.
options.whenToUse: When you need AI capabilities, machine learning models, natural language processing, or cognitive services
options.whenNotToUse: For traditional applications without AI requirements

options.label: IoT, Edge & Real-World Input
options.description: Think: What happens at the edge? IoT Hub, Device Provisioning Service (DPS), Time Series Insights, Edge Runtime.
options.whenToUse: When building IoT solutions requiring device connectivity, edge computing, or device management
options.whenNotToUse: For traditional web or mobile applications without hardware integration

options.label: Media & Content Delivery
options.description: Think: How do I handle heavy media? Media Services, Live/On-demand Streaming, Encoding, DRM, Video Indexer.
options.whenToUse: When you need video processing, live streaming, encoding, content delivery, or media analytics
options.whenNotToUse: For applications without media processing or streaming requirements

options.label: Analytics, BI & Big Data
options.description: Think: How do I turn logs and events into intelligence? Synapse, Data Factory, Databricks, Stream Analytics, Power BI.
options.whenToUse: When building enterprise data warehouses, analytics pipelines, or business intelligence solutions
options.whenNotToUse: For simple operational reporting or small-scale data processing

options.label: Service Bus
options.description: Enterprise messaging with queues and topics
options.whenToUse: Enterprise scenarios requiring advanced messaging patterns, transactions, or pub-sub
options.whenNotToUse: Simple queue scenarios where Storage Queue suffices

options.label: Event Grid
options.description: Event-driven architecture with event routing

options.whenNotToUse: When you need guaranteed message delivery or command patterns

options.label: Azure Storage Queue
options.description: A simple and cost-effective option for storing and retrieving messages in a decoupled architecture.
pros: Scalable to handle a large number of messages efficiently.
Cost-effective with a low pay-as-you-go price point.
Durable with messages stored redundantly across multiple locations.
cons: No built-in message ordering without using message sessions.
Visibility timeout may lead to duplicate processing if messages are not processed in time.
options.whenToUse: Use when you need a straightforward, low-cost solution for asynchronous messaging without complex requirements.

options.label: Azure Service Bus Queue
options.description: A more advanced messaging service that supports complex messaging patterns including ordered delivery and transactions.
pros: Supports larger message sizes (up to 256 KB for the basic tier).
Built-in message ordering and sessions for managing related messages.
Advanced features like transactions and dead-lettering for error handling.
cons: Higher cost compared to Azure Storage Queue.
More complex to configure and manage.
Overhead may not be justified for simple messaging needs.
options.whenToUse: Use when you require advanced features such as message ordering, transactions, or when handling complex workflows.

options.label: Azure Event Grid
options.description: A fully managed event routing service that enables the building of event-driven architectures.
pros: Supports a wide range of event sources and handlers.
Enables real-time event processing with minimal latency.
Easy integration with other Azure services and custom applications.
cons: Not a traditional queue; it focuses on event routing rather than message storage.
May require additional services to handle stateful processing.
Event delivery guarantees are different from traditional queues.
options.whenToUse: Use when you want to build event-driven architectures and need to react to events in real-time.

options.label: Azure Functions with Queues
options.description: Combine Azure Functions with Azure Storage Queue or Service Bus Queue to create serverless, event-driven applications.
pros: Scales automatically based on demand and usage.
Integrates seamlessly with both Storage Queue and Service Bus for flexible processing.
cons: Cold start latency can affect performance for infrequently used functions.
Complexity of function management and deployment.
Cost may increase with high volume of executions.
options.whenToUse: Use when you want to leverage serverless capabilities for processing messages automatically without managing infrastructure.

options.label: Azure Logic Apps with Queues
options.description: Use Azure Logic Apps to orchestrate workflows that interact with queues for automation and integration.
pros: Extensive connectors available for integrating with various services.
Visual designer helps in understanding and managing workflows.
cons: Can become complex for intricate workflows.
Cost may grow with increased workflow complexity and usage.
Less control over performance and execution compared to code-based solutions.
options.whenToUse: Use when you need to automate workflows that involve queues without extensive coding, particularly for business processes and integrations.

compatibilityRules.message: Event Grid and Functions work well together for event-driven architectures

compatibilityRules.message: Service Bus Queue integrates well with Premium Functions
